summary: A New York Times article detailing allegations that Jeffrey Epstein relied on a network of women, including his girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell and several employees, to recruit and manage teenage girls and young women for sexual abuse. The article reports on the ongoing federal investigation into these associates following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case, described as having an insatiable appetite for girls and relying on a network of associates to procure them for sexual abuse.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Epstein's longtime companion and alleged manager of his sex-trafficking operation
persons.context: Accused in multiple lawsuits of overseeing efforts to procure girls for Epstein, managing his homes, and introducing him to powerful social contacts. She has denied the allegations.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Accused in lawsuits of scheduling girls for sexual encounters with Epstein, keeping records of them, and escorting them within his Palm Beach mansion. Was named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 Florida plea deal.

persons.name: Haley Robson
persons.role: Recruiter for Epstein and former victim
persons.context: Recruited at age 16, she later became a recruiter herself, bringing dozens of girls from her high school to Epstein's mansion for money. She is under scrutiny by federal authorities.

persons.name: Lesley Groff
persons.context: Worked for Epstein for nearly 20 years, managing his schedule and, according to allegations, arranging travel for girls. Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Adriana Ross
persons.context: Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal. Allegedly removed computers from Epstein's Florida mansion during the police investigation.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.role: Former model, pilot, and alleged participant in abuse
persons.context: Accused of participating in sexual encounters with victims at Epstein's direction. Named as a possible co-conspirator in the 2008 plea deal and may have been an underage victim herself initially.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Said she was recruited by Maxwell at age 16 and became Epstein's 'sex slave,' also forced to have sex with his powerful acquaintances.

persons.name: Sarah Ransome
persons.context: Sued Maxwell and other associates, alleging she was recruited, given instructions on how to please Epstein, and that her weight was monitored for him.

persons.name: Teresa Helm
persons.context: Spoke at a court hearing, urging prosecutors to investigate the women in Epstein's inner circle who helped him.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Brought charges against Epstein and stated the investigation into the sex-trafficking conspiracy was ongoing after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.context: Described Maxwell as 'the boss' and testified that Adriana Ross removed computers from the mansion.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Described Ghislaine Maxwell as 'the boss' in a deposition.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: Described Sarah Kellen as 'like an assistant to Ghislaine' in a deposition.

persons.name: Spencer T. Kuvin
persons.context: Represented several accusers in lawsuits and commented that Sarah Kellen was 'really running that organization' in Palm Beach.

persons.name: Michael Bachner
persons.context: Stated his client never engaged in misconduct or knowingly made travel arrangements for anyone under 18.

persons.name: Lauren Hersh
persons.context: Commented on the legal complexity of charging associates who may have started as victims themselves.

persons.name: Douglas McIntosh
persons.context: Represented Robson in a civil case and called her 'a lovely young lady' but declined to answer questions about her involvement with Epstein.

persons.name: Robert Maxwell
persons.role: British publishing magnate, father of Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as the father of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Amy Julia Harris
persons.context: Co-author of the New York Times article.

persons.name: Frances Robles
persons.context: Co-author of the New York Times article.

persons.name: Mike Baker
persons.context: Co-author of the New York Times article.

persons.name: William K. Rashbaum
persons.context: Co-author of the New York Times article.

connections.description: Described as partners in business, with Maxwell allegedly managing his sex-trafficking operation and his social circle.
Kellen was a high-ranking employee accused of scheduling girls for sexual encounters with Epstein and managing the logistics at his Palm Beach home.
Described by the pilot as 'like an assistant to Ghislaine.' Kellen operated under Maxwell's alleged direction.
Robson was initially recruited as a teenage victim for massages, then became a recruiter for him, bringing other girls to his mansion.
Robson said Kellen would call her to arrange for girls to be available for Epstein's visits, and they would hammer out logistics together.
Groff was Epstein's executive assistant for nearly two decades, managing his schedule and, allegedly, travel for victims.
Ransome alleges Maxwell and Sarah Kellen gave her tips on how to sexually please Jeffrey Epstein.
Ransome communicated directly with Groff, who repeated Epstein's promises and with whom Ransome discussed her weight for Epstein.
Marcinkova is accused of participating in sexual encounters with victims at Epstein's direction and may have been a victim herself initially.
Giuffre says Maxwell recruited her at age 16 with promises of opportunity, leading to her becoming Epstein's 'sex slave.'

events.title: Haley Robson's Deposition
events.description: Haley Robson gave a deposition for a civil case describing her recruitment at age 16, her initial groping by Epstein, and her subsequent role as a recruiter for him.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in a Manhattan jail cell, leading federal authorities to refocus their investigation on his associates.

events.title: Victim Impact Hearing
events.description: About two dozen women offered searing accounts of sexual abuse by Epstein at a hearing in Manhattan federal court to dismiss the indictment following his death.

events.title: Florida Plea Agreement
events.description: Epstein struck a plea deal with federal prosecutors in Florida, pleading guilty to state charges and serving 13 months in jail. The deal granted immunity from prosecution to four women named as possible co-conspirators: Sarah Kellen, Lesley Groff, Adriana Ross, and Nadia Marcinkova.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: Palm Beach police investigated Epstein, during which a 16-year-old victim described a sexual encounter involving Epstein and Nadia Marcinkova. Computers were allegedly removed from the mansion by Adriana Ross.

keyFacts: Following Epstein's suicide, federal authorities refocused their investigation on more than half a dozen of his employees, girlfriends, and associates for their alleged roles in his sex-trafficking operation.

Four women—Sarah Kellen, Lesley Groff, Adriana Ross, and Nadia Marcinkova—were named as possible 'co-conspirators' and granted immunity in Epstein's 2008 Florida plea deal, but could still face charges in Manhattan.

The article describes a hierarchical operation with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell at the top, Sarah Kellen as a 'lieutenant' managing schedules, and recruiters like Haley Robson procuring girls from local schools.
Some associates, like Haley Robson and Nadia Marcinkova, are described as potentially starting as victims themselves before becoming involved in recruiting or participating in the abuse of others.
The U.S. Attorney's office in Manhattan has stated its investigation into the sex-trafficking conspiracy is not finished and it is not bound by the earlier Florida immunity agreement.
